fields.description:
When using --stop-source to block new instances from running on a node that is evacuating instances the option is not honored.

Steps:
* 2 nodes; one has zero instances running on it, the other has 2 instance store instances - each with a volume attached.
* Invoke an evacuation of the node and specify to block new instnaces from using the source node {{euca-migrate-instances --source 10.111.5.23 --stop-source}}
* Run 2 new instances in 1 reservation {{euca-run-instances -k don-key -n 2 emi-1af1f726}}
* One of the instances will start pending on the node that should be blocked and eventually be running there.

Installed Packages
Name        : eucalyptus
Arch        : x86_64
Version     : 4.0.1
Release     : 0.0.22245.37.20140725gitfa08d5e.el6

Topology
\[CLC WS UFS\]
\[CC SC\]
\[NC\]
\[NC\]
fields.summary: Cannot stop source node controller from running new instances on it

comments.body: Changing 'component' to 'Cloud Controller', as I suspect this is a CLC/EC2 problem. [~kedwards], could you assign it appropriately?
[~tony], did you recall if the node was actually stopped? (i.e. euca-describe-nodes)
[~sjones], I do not recall. I can get a setup up and confirm one way or the other.

[~sjones], When I tried to reproduce I saw that the node was disabled when migration started then went to enabled when another reservation was made during the migration.  However, the new reservation was fulfilled on the available node (ie. did not reproduce the original issue)  The topology used to reproduce here was slightly different (single front end + 2 Nodes). I will try to reproduce with the same topology. And update this issue accordingly.

{code}
[root@g-05-06 ~]# euca-migrate-instances --source 10.111.5.82 --stop-source

I meant to check what the state of the NC is after it is supposed to be disabled, but I haven't gotten around to that in 4.1.0 timeframe, unfortunately. Please, feel free to ping me next time someone is working on it. I am happy to look around.

Empyrean does not guarantee that when you stop a service it will move to the stopped state. The simplest fix is probably to update euca-migrate-instances and retry the action until the node state is STOPPED before continuing with the migration. The workaround is to use euca-modify-service or similar to stop the node manually before migrating.

Let's remove the '--stop-source' flag from the tool in 4.2.

This change will need to be documented, [~scottb]. Thanks!

Fix Verified

Installed Packages
Name        : eucalyptus
Arch        : x86_64
Version     : 4.2.0
Release     : 0.0.23996.695.20151007gitbf619d4.el6

In the new admin tools the --stop-source command is removed.
{code}
[root@g-05-07 ~]# euserv-migrate-instances --help
usage: euserv-migrate-instances (-s HOST | -i INSTANCE)
                                [--include-dest HOST | --exclude-dest HOST]
                                [-U URL] [--region USER@REGION] [-I KEY_ID]
                                [-S KEY] [--security-token TOKEN] [--debug]
                                [--debugger] [--version] [-h]

Migrate one instance from its current host, or migrate all instances
from a specific host

optional arguments:
  -s HOST, --source HOST
                        remove all instances from a specific host
  -i INSTANCE, --instance INSTANCE
                        remove one instance from its current host
  --include-dest HOST   allow migration to only a specific host (may be used
                        more than once)
  --exclude-dest HOST   allow migration to any host except a specific one (may
                        be used more than once)
  -U URL, --url URL     compute service endpoint URL
  --region USER@REGION  region and/or user names to search when looking up
                        config file data
  -I KEY_ID, --access-key-id KEY_ID
  -S KEY, --secret-key KEY
  --security-token TOKEN
  --debug               show debugging output
  --debugger            launch interactive debugger on error
  --version             show the program's version and exit
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
{code}
